text: English writing skills punctuation marks
lesson six after lesson one you may
still be asking the question which words
should be capitalized in titles it could
depend on personal preferences but in
formal writing the silent format will
likely be decided by an authority like a
publisher or a professor in any case the
key is consistency choose a format and
stick to it
there are different style and format
guides out there you can do a search
find these different guides then choose
a format stick to it an instructor may
ask you to use MLA format MLA stands for
Modern Language Association other
writers use Chicago style they follow
the Chicago Manual of style in academic
publications you'll often see APA format
APA stands for American Psychological
Association and journalism you'll
encounter the AP style The Associated
Press has their own style book
here's my own answer to the question
which words should be capitalized in
titles the first word nouns pronouns
adjectives verbs adverbs and particles
of phrasal verbs as for longer
prepositions originally I was taught to
capitalize prepositions if they had more
than three letters in recent years I've
been trying to change that practice I've
been trying not to capitalize any of my
prepositions and that's a practice that
I've seen other writers use it's advised
by at least one of the style and format
guides practice punctuate the sentences
one I'll give you a moment to edit the
sentence and then I'll tell you the
answer
answer John Travolta played likeable
characters in Saturday Night Fever and
grease first we capitalize the t and
John Travolta's name and then we
capitalize main words in the titles
those are titles of movies so we place
the words in italics to
answer in phenomenon Travolta plays a
character who develops special powers to
learn things quickly make accurate
predictions and move objects with his
mind first we're going to capitalize the
P and phenomenon and place that movie
title in italics I'll also use a comma
to set off the introductory phrase and
be sure to capitalize the T in Travolta
we do not need a comma to set off the
adjective clause because it gives
necessary information
however we will need commas to separate
the items in our series
three
answer at first George is scared by some
of his powers and the song every day is
a winding road reflects this I'm going
to use a comma to set off that
introductory phrase then I'll capitalize
the G and George because that's a proper
noun I also suggest using a comma before
the conjunction and to separate my two
independent clauses as for the song
title we're going to capitalize all the
main words adjectives nouns the verb and
we'll place that song title in double
quotation marks
for answer the song changed the world
plays when George and others learn to
see the possibilities of the human mind
this sentence needs just a little bit of
editing first we'll place the song title
and double quotation marks and we'll
capitalize the verb and the noun also
we'll capitalize the G and George again
five
answer the maturity of George Malley
contrasts with the youth of Vinnie
Barbarino the high school student that
Travolta played in the TV show Welcome
Back Kotter first we need to capitalize
names George Malley Vinnie Barbarino
Travolta Kotter the TV show title has
three words they're all principal words
important words so they need to be
capitalized a TV show is a large
artistic work so we'll place the title
in italics
we need a comma to separate the main
statement from that last phrase the long
phrase at the end it gives information
about who Vinnie Barbarino is in that
phrase there is an adjective clause that
Travolta played in the TV show Welcome
Back Kotter it's necessary to identify
the high school student no comma is
needed there
six
answer Stephen King's novel Carrie tells
the tale of another person with special
abilities but that young woman's talents
are much more frightening than George
Mally's let's start by capitalizing
letters the K in Stephen King's last
name the C in Cary that's a title of a
novel George Malley again will be
capitalized let's go back to the title
of the book the novel Carrie it is a
large artistic work so we'll place it in
italics we're also missing some
apostrophes here whose novel Stephen
King's novel whose talents that young
woman's talents and of course in George
Mally's apostrophe s will also place
double quotation marks around talents
because I'm using that in a very special
way if you know the story you'll know
that the talents aren't very kind ones
they're quite horrifying so we'll place
that in double quotation marks
let's use this final statement to review
some of the patterns we learned in this
lesson as seen in the movie The Sixth
Sense special abilities can be
burdensome to those who possess them
where's the title the title of the movie
here okay
let's capitalize the words that need to
be capitalized the is an article but
because it's the first word we're going
to capitalize it and then all the other
principal words important ones the sixth
sense we have an adjective clause at the
end do we need this to identify those
yes because if I left that adjective
Clause out it would make no sense
burdensome to those which those what
people are we talking about it's
necessary it identifies those I do not
need a comma those who possess them
those who possess the special abilities
that's all for this lesson thanks for
watching and happy studies please visit
